Prerequisites: A minimum overall grade point average of 2.750; and departmental andfaculty mentor approvals required.
Description:
(May be repeated for up to 6 credit hours) Research study under the direction of a BMS faculty
mentor.Students majoring in biology (BSCI), biotechnology (BTEC), chemistry (CHEM), integrated life sciences
(ILS) and physics (PHY) majors are eligible to enroll in this course, but must have 18 credit hours in their
major completed.

(Repeatable once for credit) Minimum of two laboratory rotations per semester by arrangement with individual
faculty members.

(Repeatable for a maximum of 6 credit hours) (Cross-listed with BMS 70196) Directed investigation under
supervision of faculty member in biomedical sciences and with prior approval.

Prerequisites: Special approval of adviser and graduate standing.
Description:
(Repeatable for credit)Research for master's level graduate students. Credits earned may be applied toward
degree requirements if department approves.

Prerequisites: Special approval of adviser and graduate standing.
Description:
Thesis students must register for a minimum of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over
several semesters if desired.

Prerequisites: BSCI 5/70517 or special approval of instructor. Graduate standing.
Description:
(Cross-listed with BMS 70220) Morphological basis for normal and disturbed functions; structure-function
relationships in human microscopic anatomy. Lectures, special laboratory and learning techniques using human
tissues.

Course Name: THEORY AND PRACTICE OF CLONING AND GENETIC ENGINEERING
Prerequisites: BSCI 5/70158 andCHEM 5/70247 or BMS 6/70268. Graduate standing.
Description:
(Cross-listed with BMS 70251) Recent advances in the development and understanding of genetic
engineering,genomic DNA organization and gene therapy will be discussed.

Description:
(Repeatable for credit) (Cross-listed with BMS 70291) Credits may be applied toward degree if department
approves.

Course Name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN CELLULAR AND MOLECULAR BIOLOGY
Description:
(Repeatable for credit) (Cross-listed with BMS 70295) Study of subject or problem of current importance.
Content dependent upon student requirements and on recent developments in field.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.

Prerequisites: BSCI 40143 or BSCI 50143 or BSCI70143; and graduate standing.
Description:
(Cross-listed with BSCI 60440 and BSCI 70440 and BMS 70440) The relevant and current topics associated
with cellular signaling is covered. Topics include receptor pharmacology, classes, and regulation, transcription
factors, cell cycle signaling, and cell-cell communication.

Description:
(Cross-listed with BMS 70449) Biophysical and biochemical concepts of integrative organ system physiology in
the human: cardiovascular, pulmonary, exercise and temperature regulation physiology.

(Cross-listed with BMS 70450) Biophysical and biochemical concepts of integrative organ system physiology in
the human: renal, gastrointestinal and endocrine physiology.

side effects, toxicity and therapeutic use of drugs.

Description: Seminar for all students in Biomedical Sciences. Repeat registration permitted.

Detailed examination of the principles of primate ethology, including evolutionary trends in ecology,
dominance, locomotion and social behavior.

Graduate-level introduction to the field of biological anthropology. Topics include genetics, human variation,
fossil and modern primates and early man.

Examination of methods of univariate and bivariate experimental design. This survey emphasizes tests of
hypothesis and estimation techniques with both classical and nonparametric procedures.

This survey of multivariate analysis in anthropology includes one-sample data exploration, multiple sample
problems and regression methods. It also includes computer applications.
(Repeatable for credit)Credits may be applied toward degree if department approves.
(Repeatable for credit)Excavation and/or field survey of miocene and/or plio-pleistocene hominid localities.

(Repeatable for credit)Study of subject or problem of current importance. Content dependent upon student
requirements and on recent developments in field.

Prerequisites: Special approval of adviser. Doctoral standing.
Description:
(Repeatable for credit)Research for doctoral students who have not yet passed candidacy
examination.

(Repeatable for credit)Doctoral dissertation, for which registration in at least two semesters is required, first of
which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.
Students must successfully complete the doctoral exam before taking this course.

(Repeatable for credit)Continuing registration of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of
dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.
